senses.de: A person who is connected to you by blood or marriage
senses.ex: I am going to visit my relatives this weekend

Tips.title: Family Connection
Tips.description: Use 'relative' for anyone related by blood or marriage, not just immediate family.
Tips.example: She discovered a relative from three generations ago.

Tips.title: Not Necessarily Close
Tips.description: 'Relative' can imply distance, suggesting a family tie without implying a close relationship.
Tips.example: I've invited a few distant relatives to the wedding.

Tips.title: Formal Tone
Tips.description: Using 'relative' can sound formal or official compared to 'family member.'
Tips.example: Please list all your relatives on the application form.

senses.de: Considered in relation to something else
senses.ex: His success was relative to his hard work

Tips.title: Comparison Required
Tips.description: 'Relative' as an adjective always implies a comparison with something else.
Tips.example: Prices are low relative to last year's rates.

Tips.title: Not Absolute
Tips.description: Emphasize that 'relative' shows something is not total or absolute in nature.
Tips.example: The benefits of the policy are relative to its costs.

Tips.title: Context Dependent
Tips.description: Point out that a 'relative' characteristic depends on conditions or context.
Tips.example: His speed is fast, relative to other beginners.

senses.de: A thing's existence, nature or value is judged in comparison with something else
senses.ex: In comedy, timing is everything - it's all relative

Tips.title: Philosophical Use
Tips.description: Note that 'relative' in philosophy often discusses concepts that depend on other factors.

Tips.title: Abstract Concepts
Tips.description: Explain using 'relative' for abstract ideas measured against something else.
Tips.example: Success is a relative term, varying for each person.

senses.de: Dependent on the circumstances or context, not absolute
senses.ex: Her happiness was relative to the amount of time she spent with her family

Tips.title: Dependent Happiness
Tips.description: Describe how 'relative' can express that feelings or states depend on specific conditions.
Tips.example: Happiness is often relative to one's expectations.

Tips.title: Circumstantial
Tips.description: Clarify 'relative' for expressing something's nature that relies on particular circumstances.
Tips.example: Feeling of safety is relative to the environment.

Applicable.wordDefinition:
Applicable means something is appropriate or suitable for a particular situation or person. For example, a law may be applicable to a certain type of crime, or a certain policy may be applicable to a specific group of people.

Applicable refers to something that is fitting for a specific situation, while relative refers to something that is compared to something else.

Comparative.wordDefinition:
Both comparative and relative refer to a relation or comparison between two things, but they are used in different contexts.

Comparative is used when comparing two or more things, indicating which of them has a higher or lower degree of a certain quality.

For example, if we say that one book is more interesting than another, we are using a comparative form.

In summary, while comparative refers to the comparison between two or more things, relative refers to the relationship or connection between them.

Connect.wordDefinition:
Connect refers to a relationship or association between two or more things, such as connecting two dots with a line.

It can also refer to establishing communication or a relationship with someone, such as connecting with a friend on social media.

Kin.wordDefinition:
Kin usually refers to a person's immediate family members, such as parents, siblings, and children.

If you're talking specifically about your close family members, you might use the word kin, but if you're talking about family members in general, you might use the word "relative."

Pertinent.wordDefinition:
Pertinent refers to something that is directly related to or applicable to a particular situation or topic. For example, if you are discussing a specific problem or situation, a pertinent comment or solution would be one that directly addresses that issue.

Pertinent is more focused and specific to a particular situation, while relative is broader and more comparative.

Proportional.wordDefinition:
The term proportional refers to the relationship between two quantities that change together in a consistent and predictable way.

For example, if you increase the length of a rectangle by 2 units, the width should also increase by a proportional amount to maintain the same ratio of length to width.

Proportional describes the relationship between two quantities that change together in a consistent and predictable way, while relative describes how something compares to something else.

Relation.wordDefinition:
Relation refers to a connection or association between two or more things or people. For example, the relation between a mother and a child is a familial connection.

Relation refers to a connection or association between two or more things or people, while relative refers to a person who is related to you by blood or marriage.

Relevant.wordDefinition:
Relevant means something that is important or related to a specific topic or situation. For example, if you say "this article is relevant to our discussion on climate change," it means that the article is important and related to the topic of climate change.

Relative is applicable when comparing or connecting things, while relevant is applicable when something is important or related to a specific topic or situation.

quotes.Text: I have a relatively sunny spirit, and I always had the expectation that my path through life would be relatively sunny, no matter what happened. I have never allowed myself to be bitter.
quotes.Title: German Statesman
quotes.Name: Angela Merkel

quotes.Text: And that's another reason to make this movie: We can put plays on film now, at a relatively small cost, and they will reach an audience they would never have reached otherwise.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Dustin Hoffman

quotes.Text: Nobody has ever before asked the nuclear family to live all by itself in a box the way we do. With no relatives, no support, we've put it in an impossible situation.
quotes.Title: American Scientist
quotes.Name: Margaret Mead

quotes.Text: In our sport you're very lucky to find a horse of a lifetime and I found mine relatively early. He's done everything for me and I owe him the world.
quotes.Title: British Royalty
quotes.Name: Zara Phillips

quotes.Text: If a man's character is to be abused there's nobody like a relative to do the business.
quotes.Title: English Poet
quotes.Name: Alexander Pope

quotes.Text: Relative to other economies in the world, India has a good feel to it.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Michael Dell

quotes.Text: I have developed a life which seems to need a relatively high income.
quotes.Title: English Actor
quotes.Name: Jeremy Irons

quotes.Text: I'm not afraid to admit that I'm a relatively slow reader.
quotes.Title: Actress
quotes.Name: Kate Winslet

quotes.Text: Politics and power is a realm of relative influence.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Fareed Zakaria

quotes.Text: I live very well, but I support a lot of relatives.
quotes.Title: American Comedian
quotes.Name: Joan Rivers
